Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: LTREB: The Next Decade in Continuing Long-Term Demographic Research on Florida Scrub Plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project continues a long-term study of the population biology of plants in Florida scrub, an endangered habitat supporting many species found nowhere else in the world. The past research includes 20 years of data on the locations, sizes, growth, and survival of > 47,000 plants, coupled with numerous experiments on plants, seeds, and the scrub habitat. The goals of this research are to expand data collection, including data on many more species collected over larger landscapes, and to answer questions in basic ecology and applied conservation. Specific topics include the effects of various fire management strategies on risks of extinction, how populations respond to variation in the vegetation structure and weather, and how introduced populations in ecological restorations can provide insight into basic biology.

Many environmental issues can only be addressed with the perspective of long-term data and with data-sharing, both outcomes of this research. For example, long-term data on plant population responses to the direct and indirect effects of weather can be useful in assessing the effects of climate change on these endangered ecosystems. This research will also provide access to students (including members of under-represented groups) from, high school to graduate school, to diverse scientific methods and studies. Moreover, this research has immediate practical applications that will be encouraged through continuing interactions with a diversity of conservation professionals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With support from the National Science Foundation for much of the time, we have studied populations of plants in a shrubland known as Florida scrub, for 26 years. We collect detailed data on the survival, growth, flowering, seed production, and seedling recruitment on 14 plant species, many of which are endangered. From these data, we have learned how long plants live, what habitats they prefer, what pollinates them, what disperses their seeds, and many other details of their life history. These Florida scrub plants grow in areas that are periodically burned by lightning and prescribed fires, although different species vary in their fire requirements.  We use our long-term data to create models of population change under different fire regimes, and can then recommend to land managers how often and under what conditions publically protected areas should be burned to promote viable populations of scrub plants.

                Building on these long-term data, we have made additional observations and performed many field experiments to get at the mechanisms of population change. For example, we have studied the dynamics of natural gaps (i.e. areas of bare sand, devoid of vegetation) among dominant shrubs and how these gaps affect the presence and abundance of herbaceous plants. Many of these species require gaps of a certain size. Fires increase gap sizes while during inter-fire periods, gaps shrink and fragment. This provides a mechanism for understanding why fire is important to many species. We have experimentally expanded gaps, showing that this can increase survival, growth, and recruitment in some species. We have also used this information to design experimental introductions with the rarest plant species, which help answer basic ecological questions as well as help recover these rare plants.

                Our research program also has had a focus on education. We expose high school students to our research by employing them as summer research assistants. We also have a thriving post-baccalaureate research intern program that leads interested students through independent research. We also host research by graduate students and interpret our results and conservation efforts to the general public through tours and talks. We also have made it a priority to post data and metadata and share our data through collaborations with other scientists. The long-term nature and large sample sizes of our datasets makes them valuable for addressing a wide range of ecological questions.
